commit_message:
Use a certbot pre-hook to ensure haproxy backend is up before renewal

We use the built in python3 http server to bring up a temporary backend
on the node which wants to renew a certificate. The timeout set so that
the haproxy health check has noticed the backend come up before certbot
runs.

There is otherwise a race condition between the haproxy healthcheck and
the certbot challenge request arriving at the acme-challenge endpoint.

Change-Id: I2f5f9457c43c68f2881bf9d44f43434ca7b43859

commit_message:
Fail check jobs if logs collection failed

When patch breaks logs collection, the job still pass and it may
be merged.
Fail job in check pipeline if logs collection fails, only for this
repository. Don't fail in gate to avoid gate reset.

Related patch: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/722645
Change-Id: Ic532e15ff3d36f41d5366e3b1bd2e54b1980fcff

[{'created': '2020-04-28 06:57:02.000000000', 'message': "Make _create_ports keys coherent with Neutron API.

OpenStackSDK have renamed some fields for Neutron API to be able to
create port object with attributes named after those fields. In our
workaround, we didn't spot that, so that all of the neutron API port
fields which prefixes started from 'binding_' cause an exception on the
neutron API call side.

In this patch we fix this by changing those fields to be acceptable
directly by Neutron API.

Note, that _create_ports is a workaround, which will be removed when
kuryr-kubernetes will bump openstakcsdk version to minimum 0.42 in
lower constraints.

Closes-bug: 1874276
Change-Id: Id36a00b94f9df837c49ced7155f8117fe9625fc2
(cherry picked from commit 473a6061500dfc7bdde4eb5c02a9006dc7982d0d)

commit_message:
Make _create_ports keys coherent with Neutron API.

OpenStackSDK have renamed some fields for Neutron API to be able to
create port object with attributes named after those fields. In our
workaround, we didn't spot that, so that all of the neutron API port
fields which prefixes started from 'binding_' cause an exception on the
neutron API call side.

In this patch we fix this by changing those fields to be acceptable
directly by Neutron API.

Note, that _create_ports is a workaround, which will be removed when
kuryr-kubernetes will bump openstakcsdk version to minimum 0.42 in
lower constraints.

Closes-bug: 1874276
Change-Id: Id36a00b94f9df837c49ced7155f8117fe9625fc2
(cherry picked from commit 473a6061500dfc7bdde4eb5c02a9006dc7982d0d)

commit_message:
mock out ProviderConfiguration.__init__

In some environments unit tests fails due to tests attempting to
access /etc/neutron/ and not having permission to do so. Let's
mock out add_provider_configuration to avoid this behaviour in
unit test environment.

Change-Id: If385c26e4a6bd9eca5bd873df4d25a2d888dd9a9
Closes-Bug: #1872514

subject: Use domain_name instead of domain_id
messages: [{'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2020-05-05 16:02:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2020-05-05 16:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-05-06 09:07:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-05-07 17:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-05 16:02:10.000000000', 'message': "Use domain_name instead of domain_id

... because domain name is more predictable than domain id. Also, we
generally use domain_name instead of domain_id in other puppet modules,
so it's more consistent to use domain_name.

commit_message:
Use domain_name instead of domain_id

... because domain name is more predictable than domain id. Also, we
generally use domain_name instead of domain_id in other puppet modules,
so it's more consistent to use domain_name.

Change-Id: Ibd38fcfd9cec7f266d35fd9851a8a744b497d32a

subject: OVN: Add ovn_emit_need_to_frag configuration option
messages:
[{'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2020-05-05 12:36:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2020-05-05 12:37:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't know why this change is not included already in stable/train. The original patch was merged around 7mo ago... Perhaps we missed it for a few days/weeks :-(

The change is included in stable/train for networking-ovn."}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-05-06 09:08:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-05-07 14:17:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-05 12:36:29.000000000', 'message': 'OVN: Add ovn_emit_need_to_frag configuration option

This patch is adding a new configuration option called
"ovn_emit_need_to_frag" to be set in the "ovn" section of
etc/neutron/plugins/ml2_conf.ini.

When set to True the option tells ovn whether it should emit "need to
frag" packets in case of MTU mismatch. Before enabling this configuration
make sure that its supported by the host kernel (version >= 5.2) or by
checking the output of the following command: ovs-appctl -t ovs-vswitchd
dpif/show-dp-features br-int | grep "Check pkt length action". Defaults
to False.

This option was intruced by networking-ovn at:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671766/

Change-Id: I258402e8033726aa9abf2dc5f801fdf724ab9e3a
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3478011d64fcf57fa8d034f10621ce48cb5aff88)
'}]
commit_message:
OVN: Add ovn_emit_need_to_frag configuration option

This patch is adding a new configuration option called
"ovn_emit_need_to_frag" to be set in the "ovn" section of
etc/neutron/plugins/ml2_conf.ini.

When set to True the option tells ovn whether it should emit "need to
frag" packets in case of MTU mismatch. Before enabling this configuration
make sure that its supported by the host kernel (version >= 5.2) or by
checking the output of the following command: ovs-appctl -t ovs-vswitchd
dpif/show-dp-features br-int | grep "Check pkt length action". Defaults
to False.

This option was intruced by networking-ovn at:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671766/

Change-Id: I258402e8033726aa9abf2dc5f801fdf724ab9e3a
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3478011d64fcf57fa8d034f10621ce48cb5aff88)

subject: Fix Self-Signed Certificates failed
messages:
[{'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-04-29 03:24:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-04-29 06:14:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-04-29 06:34:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-04-29 07:35:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

this looks shady and has coverage far from complete - better find out why it fails to pick up the CA cert'}, {'account_id': 22165, 'date': '2020-04-29 15:21:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

seems you just disable it but not fix any more'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-04-30 02:48:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> seems you just disable it but not fix any more

sometimes upstreams failed to provide system certification function which will block the self signed certification to work on the the kolla.
to disable  validate_certs in uri module in kolla_toolbox will 100 percent bypass the faulty of upstreams system'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-04-30 02:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

rechecks'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-04-30 04:36:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30810, 'date': '2020-04-30 15:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Instead of disabling validation, could you try passing the openstack certificate in kolla-toolbox uri execution?  

    module_name: uri
    module_args:
      url: "{{ elasticsearch_url }}/_cluster/settings"
      method: PUT
      status_code: 200
      return_content: yes
      body: "{{ elasticsearch_shard_body | to_json }}"
      body_format: json
      client_cert: "{{ openstack_cacert | | default(omit) }}"
  delegate_to: "{{ groups['elasticsearch'][0] }}"
  run_once: true'}, {'account_id': 30810, 'date': '2020-05-04 23:32:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-05-07 06:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-05-07 07:15:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2020-05-07 07:16:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 30810, 'date': '2020-05-07 17:09:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks for the output upload. It looks like it didn't fail due to self signed cert validation, but an SSL parsing failure.

1. Did you use the Kolla Ansible certification generation task to generate your cert?
2. Could you validate that you run into this issue if you deploy on an Ubuntu based openstack deploy?"}]

Final RC patch for senlin-dashboard

This creates a new RC before final release candidate ending to release latest fixes and translations.

Please ack with +1, or if there is some reason to hold off leave a -1.

commit_message:
Add a 600s timeout when creating enable-ssh-admin workflow

If enable-ssh-admin.sh workflow fails, the script was looping forever,
because it only checks if the workflow is SUCCESSFUL.

Now, we have a timeout of 500 seconds and when it reaches it, it'll stop
and print a debug message.

Note: we're using ENABLE_SSH_ADMIN_TIMEOUT variable which can be
overriden when calling the script; the default value was taken from
tripleoclient/constants.

Change-Id: Ie183321bc23164745237d7036885f6e6dcfef859
Closes-Bug: #1876646

commit_message:
Remove monotonic usage

The monotonic package was needed for monotonic time operations when
running under Python runtimes older than 3.3. Since we now only support
versions higher than this, this third party package requirement can now
be removed.

Change-Id: Ie99411882822a5db47462fcb2748c6e978587b8c
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Update master for stable/ussuri

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/ussuri.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/ussuri.

Change-Id: I35b412e4f2fd9d2ba995149b11a87ef2fe9e961b
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Update Advanced Config guide to clarify paths

This update clears up an additional path that was mentioned in the
Advanced Configuration documentation, but not actually picked up in the
playbooks.

This specifically affects Service Configuration overrides. The docs have
been cleaned up to reflect the way the playbooks pick up the override
files.

Change-Id: Id15fe139af6462217c2ac26d7d21c5eac5368e12
Closes-Bug: 1873782
Signed-off-by: Raimund Hook <openstack@sting-ray.za.net>
(cherry picked from commit 08682243ed534366ff7ef52a538e14ad04d01f1c)

'}, {'created': '2019-10-23 17:43:48.000000000', 'message': "tox: Keeping going with docs

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.
2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Depends-On: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e
Change-Id: I27f7cb49a634f6131752d7e4a15929b3edcda4d4

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-04 22:30:07.000000000', 'message': 'Remove monotonic usage

The monotonic package was needed for monotonic time operations when
running under Python runtimes older than 3.3. Since we now only support
versions higher than this, this third party package requirement can now
be removed.

Change-Id: I7aa3b46a51e416f1c949538301be2365c39047ed
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Remove monotonic usage

The monotonic package was needed for monotonic time operations when
running under Python runtimes older than 3.3. Since we now only support
versions higher than this, this third party package requirement can now
be removed.

Change-Id: I7aa3b46a51e416f1c949538301be2365c39047ed
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Creating the Testing and Collaboration Tools SIG

The OpenStack-side of the Infrastructure team work is now better
served by a SIG, centered around maintaining the testing tooling
and cooperation with the Opendev team.

Jeremy agreed to bootstrap the leadership team there.

Change-Id: I327eff0e7353ed402362455453c869995c1a4ce5

commit_message:
Update Advanced Config guide to clarify paths

Advanced Configuration documentation, but not actually picked up in the
playbooks.

This specifically affects Service Configuration overrides. The docs have
been cleaned up to reflect the way the playbooks pick up the override
files.

commit_message:
Disable checking of image url for master

Sometimes, promotion pipeline fails and images are not available on
image server leading to give 404 on molecule tests.

Adding  validate_on: rdo in release file disables the checking.

Change-Id: I5426227202a808eaa7a7c22910a3a38a193a45ef
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
python_keystoneclient: fix test breakage

Python-keystoneclient unit tests are broken because of hardcoded
token expiration data. This patch fixed them.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/702262/

So add it as a patch since stable/pike is already EM status.

Change-Id: I35cb25c3065785a5fc40a31a4fea265bdaef20e8

commit_message:
Add role for Container file(s) generation

This change creates a role that implements the Dockerfile specification via
simple template, which will allow us to generate our container files based on
our current needs. When container files are generated, both a Dockerfile
and Buildah script will be created in the selected base path. This will maintain
flexability in our build choices.

Change-Id: I86102fe7075fd6918644e3e981a28e0b31ae9694
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
CephRgw healthcheck aligned with ceph-ansible

ceph-ansible specifies GET in the healthcheck
option and this patch just aligns the haproxy
rgw section to the ceph-ansible specs.

Change-Id: I2de78f17ebb5ff50566c4f53f3377322018525d1
(cherry picked from commit d4d03ad0983a918951c8dff7612c8c67e6be0e15)

commit_message:
Remove special nb04 config file

With nb01/02.opendev.org now being Ansible/container builders, all
builders can use the same config.  This moves the nb04 config back to
nodepool.yaml and unpauses everything except gentoo, which is still
constantly failing.

Change-Id: I55cfedb9ac7fa06ba1725f0ec92f7247237dc74b

commit_message:
Remove cinder spec from osd-devices

The test specification doesn't need the 'cinder' spec as part of the osd
devices, and this patchset brings it in line with the other bundles.

Change-Id: If13f38eea33f3d83133396e01eff0b36eb90e82a

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1063, 'name': 'Ed Leafe', 'email': 'ed@leafe.com', 'username': 'ed-leafe'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 9708, 'name': 'Balazs Gibizer', 'display_name': 'gibi', 'email': 'gibizer@gmail.com', 'username': 'gibi'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 15:45:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 15:55:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

How did you generate this? Script something up to check each entry against a pip freeze output in a placement venv? Or just eyeballs?'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 15:58:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> How did you generate this? Script something up to check each entry
 > against a pip freeze output in a placement venv? Or just eyeballs?

Side by side eyeballs in a split vim window between the file and the output of 'pip list'.

Identified some packages that are missing from lower-constraints.txt that are in the test envs. I'm unclear on whether the goal is to have _everything_ in lower-constraints?"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 16:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Talking with smcginnis it migh be easier to pip freeze a work env and upload that.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 16:52:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 16:58:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Let's update keystonemiddleware in requirements.txt as well."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:00:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

thanks, too many eggs

(that's almost a pun)"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:43:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:43:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:44:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

Wait a minute, are you sure this is pip freeze from lower-constraints and not upper-constraints?'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:46:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Wait a minute, are you sure this is pip freeze from lower-constraints and not upper-constraints?

In other words, it looks like anything that wasn't removed and was updated, has been updated to the version in upper-constraints, which I'm thinking we shouldn't do unless something fails tests without an update, like keystonemiddleware."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:47:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Wait a minute, are you sure this is pip freeze from
 > lower-constraints and not upper-constraints?

It's lower-constraints inherited from nova, building a lower-constraints test environment using the new method, with the included packages demanding what it needs. If it was upper-constraints, then alembic would be a higher version: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/tree/upper-constraints.txt#n516"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 17:50:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

> > Wait a minute, are you sure this is pip freeze from
 > lower-constraints and not upper-constraints?
 > 
 > In other words, it looks like anything that wasn't removed and was
 > updated, has been updated to the version in upper-constraints,
 > which I'm thinking we shouldn't do unless something fails tests
 > without an update, like keystonemiddleware.

Feh, I guess you're right. This is a pain. There's no good way to automate the generation because this shows that a freeze isn't good enough. I'll fix it."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-31 18:10:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-11-06 17:54:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Why not just unset 'use_develop'? We have a setup.py file, right?"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-06 18:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

> Why not just unset 'use_develop'? We have a setup.py file, right?

Lord knows. I thought I had tried that but I guess not. I think I was too far down a hole to see. There's been a lot of that lately as I try to peel off the layers of "stuff that was just copied in".'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-06 18:37:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Why not just unset 'use_develop'? We have a setup.py file, right?

Oh, I see. It looks like pbr uses a customised install (via distutils?) when it is detects its in a checkout. In my (outside-of-openstack) experience setup.py install and setup.py develop both install dependencies, the difference is whether there is a symlink. Am I wrong that that's the norm?"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-06 19:05:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-11-19 23:29:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Case in point: check out this revision, rebase it, and tox -r -elower-constraints. Some tests will fail.

tox -r -epy36 they won't

Take out the install_command in lower-constraints and tox -r -e again, and it will not fail because upper will "win". We need it to fail to tell us that lower-constraints.txt is wrong. In this case it is that oslotest is too old a version.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-31 15:45:24.000000000', 'message': "Remove unused packages from lower-constraints.txt

Remove packages that don't show up in a placement environment
from lower-constraints.txt. This shouldn't change things in any
functional way, but keeps the file a bit more tidy and short.

Change-Id: Id66a28f7ace6fc2adf0e1201d9de5f901234d870
"}, {'created': '2018-10-31 16:52:52.000000000', 'message': "Correct lower-constraints.txt and the related tox job

While exploring removing unused packages from lower-constraints.txt it
became clear that the lower-constraints job was not working as expected:
Because our tox config has usedevelop=True 'setup.py develop' is called
to install the placement package after the install command is called.
This means that the lower-constraints are clobbered.

This change makes it so that we call pip again after placement is
installed to put the versions of code in lower-constraints into the text
environment. Then all the test (unit and functional) are run to see if
the versions are correct.

This flagged up a few changes, the main one being that we did not have
a new enough version of keystonemiddlware in order to require use of
www_authenticate_uri.

The end result here is a lower-constraints.txt file that starts from
the lower-constraints.txt defined by nova, and then is adapted to
update the versions of packages that were not up to date, remove
those packages which are no longer present, and add some are now
required.

Change-Id: Id66a28f7ace6fc2adf0e1201d9de5f901234d870

"}, {'created': '2018-10-31 18:10:52.000000000', 'message': "Correct lower-constraints.txt and the related tox job

While exploring removing unused packages from lower-constraints.txt it
became clear that the lower-constraints job was not working as expected:
Because our tox config has usedevelop=True 'setup.py develop' is called
to install the placement package after the install command is called.
This means that the lower-constraints are clobbered.

This change makes it so that we call pip again after placement is
installed to put the versions of code in lower-constraints into the test
environment. Then all the tests (unit and functional) are run to see if
the versions are correct.

This flagged up a few changes, the main one being that we did not have
a new enough version of keystonemiddleware in order to require use of
www_authenticate_uri. requirements.txt is updated for this as well.

Also a newer version of pycopg2 was required, in order to be able to
build for postgres 10 (which happens to be what's local to my box).

And PasteDeploy needed to be updated to work with Python 3's notion
of namespace packages.

The end result here is a lower-constraints.txt file that starts from
the lower-constraints.txt defined by nova, and then is adapted to
update the versions of packages that were not up to date, remove
those packages which are no longer present, and add some are now
required.

"}, {'created': '2018-11-06 19:05:59.000000000', 'message': "Correct lower-constraints.txt and the related tox job

While exploring removing unused packages from lower-constraints.txt it
became clear that the lower-constraints job was not working as expected:
Because our tox config has usedevelop=True 'setup.py develop' is called
to install the placement package after the install command is called.
This means that the lower-constraints are clobbered.

I had mistakenly assumed that turning off 'usedevelop', which causes
'setup.py install' would not make any difference, because it usually
installs dependencies too. It turns out however, that when using pbr
and within a git working dir, it does not. That took some time to
figure out. Oh well.

This change makes it so that we create the tox environment using
usedevelop=False and with our own install_command, to avoid upper
constraints conflicting with lower constraints.

This flagged up a few changes, the main one being that we did not have
a new enough version of keystonemiddleware in order to require use of
www_authenticate_uri. requirements.txt is updated for this as well.

And PasteDeploy needed to be updated to work with Python 3's notion
of namespace packages.

psycopg2 need a newer version to work with Postgresql 10.

The end result here is a lower-constraints.txt file that starts from
the lower-constraints.txt defined by nova, and then is adapted to
update the versions of packages that were not up to date, remove
those packages which are no longer present, and add some that are
now required.

Change-Id: Id66a28f7ace6fc2adf0e1201d9de5f901234d870

cmd.test_manage use features to control what is capture by the Output
fixture from oslotest. Note that the lower-constraints job found
this problem and also demonstrates why we must run the lower-constraints
job without upper-constraints being involved. upper-constraints will
"win" and we don't want that. The point of the job is find packages

update the versions of packages that were not up to date, remove

now required.

commit_message:
Correct lower-constraints.txt and the related tox job

While exploring removing unused packages from lower-constraints.txt it
became clear that the lower-constraints job was not working as expected:
Because our tox config has usedevelop=True 'setup.py develop' is called
to install the placement package after the install command is called.
This means that the lower-constraints are clobbered.

I had mistakenly assumed that turning off 'usedevelop', which causes
'setup.py install' would not make any difference, because it usually
installs dependencies too. It turns out however, that when using pbr
and within a git working dir, it does not. That took some time to
figure out. Oh well.

This change makes it so that we create the tox environment using
usedevelop=False and with our own install_command, to avoid upper
constraints conflicting with lower constraints.

This flagged up a few changes, the main one being that we did not have
a new enough version of keystonemiddleware in order to require use of
www_authenticate_uri. requirements.txt is updated for this as well.

And PasteDeploy needed to be updated to work with Python 3's notion
of namespace packages.

psycopg2 need a newer version to work with Postgresql 10.

oslotest needs to be raised to 3.4.0 because the tests in
cmd.test_manage use features to control what is capture by the Output
fixture from oslotest. Note that the lower-constraints job found
this problem and also demonstrates why we must run the lower-constraints
job without upper-constraints being involved. upper-constraints will
"win" and we don't want that. The point of the job is find packages
where lower-constraints are wrong, so it must "win".

The end result here is a lower-constraints.txt file that starts from
the lower-constraints.txt defined by nova, and then is adapted to
update the versions of packages that were not up to date, remove
those packages which are no longer present, and add some that are
now required.

Change-Id: Id66a28f7ace6fc2adf0e1201d9de5f901234d870

commit_message:
Prioritize port create and update ready messages

The DHCP agent prioritizes RPC messages based on the
priority field send from neutron-server, but then groups
them all in the same dhcp_ready_ports set when sending
them back to the server to clear the provisioning block(s).

Priority should be given to new and changed ports, since
those are most likely to be associated with new instances
which can fail to boot if they are not handled quickly when
the agent is very busy, for example, right after it was
restarted.

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/unit/agent/dhcp/test_agent.py

Change-Id: Ib5074abadd7189bb4bdd5e46c677f1bfb071221e
Closes-bug: #1864675
(cherry picked from commit 113dfac6083c2bda36f5186e123e4e5c82fa8097)

[{'created': '2020-05-04 11:11:00.000000000', 'message': '[ovn] Add PortBinding delete event for external ports

The ports are unbound from chassis before they get deleted after VM with
normal VIF ports is deleted. In case of SRIOV, we do not unbound the
external SRIOV port but we delete it right away with chassis column set.

This patch adds DELETE event type support to the event that tears down
the metadata datapath. Also a warning is added if bound port that is not
external is being removed.

Change-Id: I17b71933b8c3a7609fcc5027c246f5b03d493ee2
(cherry-picked manually from 76a2f8b33e3f673b96feeb2724ae55567a3b6520)

commit_message:
[ovn] Add PortBinding delete event for external ports

The ports are unbound from chassis before they get deleted after VM with
normal VIF ports is deleted. In case of SRIOV, we do not unbound the
external SRIOV port but we delete it right away with chassis column set.

This patch adds DELETE event type support to the event that tears down
the metadata datapath. Also a warning is added if bound port that is not
external is being removed.

Change-Id: I17b71933b8c3a7609fcc5027c246f5b03d493ee2
(cherry-picked manually from 76a2f8b33e3f673b96feeb2724ae55567a3b6520)
Closes-Bug: #1875865
Signed-off-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>

Based on debug performed in [1] the TestVirtualPorts
are unstable. At lease one of tests per 20
retries of functional job fail in various
places.
We don't think it is worth to spend more
time on debugging those tests, because there is
a possible easier solution: set virtual port
type based on DEVICE_TYPE, and do not rely
on allowed address pairs.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/712888/

(cherry-picked from neutron Iffef8ceb9ca458820a7b3e604a53281f7e93b810)

Change-Id: I1d576c94815de3b8f07c64936006477d1938d88c

commit_message:
Mark TestVirtualPorts tests as unstable

Based on debug performed in [1] the TestVirtualPorts
are unstable. At lease one of tests per 20
retries of functional job fail in various
places.
We don't think it is worth to spend more
time on debugging those tests, because there is
a possible easier solution: set virtual port
type based on DEVICE_TYPE, and do not rely
on allowed address pairs.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/712888/

(cherry-picked from neutron Iffef8ceb9ca458820a7b3e604a53281f7e93b810)

Change-Id: I1d576c94815de3b8f07c64936006477d1938d88c
Related-Bug: #1865453
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
rbd: Use showmapped to find the root RBD device during disconnect_volume

The original method of unmapping the higher level RBD device found under
/dev/rbd/{pool}/{volume} fails when an encryptor has been attached to
the volume locally. This is due to a symlink being created that points
to the the decrypted dm-crypt device, breaking any attempt to unmap the
RBD volume.

To avoid this we can simply find and unmap the lower level RBD device of
/dev/rbd*.

Change-Id: Id507109df80391699074773f4787f74507c4b882

commit_message:
Remove six library from dependencies

Since we're not testing or supporting Python 2 anymore, we can
convert six calls to Python 3 and get rid of it.

Change-Id: I474c01ab6ed60aecf16524935f2866e76a66569a

[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2019-03-26 13:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-03-26 14:01:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Unfortunately I think this was a bug in the centos7 kernel that we have to cover up. we can try and revert this but it's likely to add problems in upstream CI until we get CentOS8 so we might have to leave it or put it back"}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-03-26 14:10:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I understand the desire of removing this patch but it is going to break upstream CI and we know it, because of the older kernel on centos7.

What I suggest is to send a downstream revert and then revert upstream once we have CI running under centos8.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2019-03-26 15:53:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

When I was debugging an actual failure locally I saw this code failing to retry because the container already exists. Are you actually sure this is buying us what you think it is in CI?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2019-04-08 13:25:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2019-05-13 14:26:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2019-05-13 14:26:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2020-05-07 14:40:33.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Revert: docker-puppet: retry container run command

We agreed to revert this as it makes real failures take longer
to show up.

Change-Id: I0fa085c8bc795aed5d6ce30a350276eaf7ee17cf
Related-Bug: #1811383

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ic7d659156da39d9f9311a9615ad6ce2222d5f3d6

commit_message:
parameterize generation of the kill scripts

Generate kill scripts only for processes that are being run as side car
containers. This is required because the kill scripts assume that the
process being sent SIGKILL, SIGHUP, etc are running into a container and
can end up sending the signal to the parent agent if they are not.

Change-Id: Iae74a9fe35329a6d3a1e1812311c4295b67eb9f1

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-24 15:00:22.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: convert systemd wrappers to use named pipes

There are some issues with using notifications based on systemd.path
that were causing races in restarting sidecar containers. This patch
switches the processes file to be a named pipe and the sync service to
be a running service instead of a oneshot.

Advantages:
 - no need to rely on systemd notifictions, removing a potential source
   of races
 - as this is a case of single producer/single consumer and named pipe
   writes are atomic up to 4k, there is no need for locking

TODO:
 - do we need migration from one systemd wrapper version to this one
   (i.e. convert process files from regular files to pipes)
 = the sync service is horribly naively written. There *has* to be stuff
   needed to make it proper

Change-Id: I1cc7255626eda08a64542140fa03c0a27fbd4f92
Closes-Bug: #1874470

commit_message:
convert systemd wrappers to use named pipes

There are some issues with using notifications based on systemd.path
that were causing races in restarting sidecar containers. This patch
switches the processes file to be a named pipe and the sync service to
be a running service instead of a oneshot.

Advantages:
 - no need to rely on systemd notifictions, removing a potential source
   of races
 - as this is a case of single producer/single consumer and named pipe
   writes are atomic up to 4k, there is no need for locking making
   things much simpler
 - did I mention it was dead simple

TODO:
 - do we need migration from one systemd wrapper version to this one
   (i.e. convert process files from regular files to pipes). This
   belongs in templates update/upgrade tasks
 = the sync service is horribly naively written. There *has* to be stuff
   needed to make it proper. At the moment there isn't anything glaring
   but there may be some things to improve stability/recovery in
   unexpected situations

Change-Id: I1cc7255626eda08a64542140fa03c0a27fbd4f92
Closes-Bug: #1874470

commit_message:
Remove the release note job

The networking-ovn has no master anymore, it has been removed at
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/715174/ because the code has now moved
to another repository (openstack/neutron).

Due to this, the release note job will fail and should be removed as
stated in a comment by Andreas at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/704898/

Change-Id: I13c055a8d971dd059ba2ace6f35bcc708b7654af
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

messages: [{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-04-27 09:07:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-05-07 13:24:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-27 09:07:31.000000000', 'message': "Break out py27 job templates

To allow non-py27 supporting repos to use shade job templates, this
breaks out the py27 and py3 jobs into separate templates. Relevant repos
can then continue to use the existing template names without picking up
the unsupported job runtimes they no longer need.

Remove the py27-tips jobs - they just don't make any sense any more.

Change-Id: Ia211e31723ede592f19a8df6c18e45699ca25788
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3db89db8c611e9bc96ea5c7737d160f1700421fc)
"}]
commit_message:
Break out py27 job templates

To allow non-py27 supporting repos to use shade job templates, this
breaks out the py27 and py3 jobs into separate templates. Relevant repos
can then continue to use the existing template names without picking up
the unsupported job runtimes they no longer need.

Remove the py27-tips jobs - they just don't make any sense any more.

Change-Id: Ia211e31723ede592f19a8df6c18e45699ca25788
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3db89db8c611e9bc96ea5c7737d160f1700421fc)

commit_message:
Improve `restricted_parameters` validator to cover None case

Validator raised the following error in case of None as target

  AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get'

Change-Id: I23b7231ccf2f9e6982612fc7733375190ab7fc98

commit_message:
Bump librdkafka to 1.4.0

Package confluent-kafka-python v1.4.1 requires librdkafka >= 1.4.0 [1]
Bump sublibraries libressl3.0-libcrypto libressl3.0-libssl

[1] https://github.com/confluentinc/confluent-kafka-python/tree/v1.4.1#prerequisites

Change-Id: I005c16dc2c2c11548d4cdce023599fb9be03a52f

fallback on DNS. The environment variable must be not defined,
if the value is an empty string. This might be fixed in a future:
https://github.com/ansible-collections/community.general/pull/241
This change also adds a note to the description, because in case

commit_message:
Make sure IdMServer is optional

When IPA_HOST is an empty string, the ansible module doesn't
fallback on DNS. The environment variable must be not defined,
if the value is an empty string. This might be fixed in a future:
https://github.com/ansible-collections/community.general/pull/241
This change also adds a note to the description, because in case
the server is provided, the domain is required:
https://pagure.io/freeipa/issue/3912

Change-Id: Idf38c234e50442aed082d9a0ebbd488344d50a90

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-17 19:14:16.000000000', 'message': "NetApp ONTAP: Fix iSCSI multiattach volume terminates connection

When detaching a volume from an instance, NetApp ONTAP driver terminates
the iSCSI connection, even if there're other connections to the LUN from
the same initiator. This terminates connections to the LUN from other
instances running on the same host.

This patch fixes this bug by leaving the connection untouched if there
are other connections from the same initiator.

Change-Id: I0b8b5930c9e8f3c049b82e92c5fb7b05d6ae9291
Closes-Bug: #1839384
"}, {'created': '2020-03-20 21:05:40.000000000', 'message': "NetApp ONTAP: Fix iSCSI multiattach volume terminates connection

When detaching a volume from an instance, NetApp ONTAP driver terminates
the iSCSI connection, even if there're other connections to the LUN from
the same initiator. This terminates connections to the LUN from other
instances running on the same host.

This patch fixes this bug by leaving the connection untouched if there
are other connections from the same initiator. Now the connection is
terminated only if it's the last one from the same initiator.

Change-Id: I0b8b5930c9e8f3c049b82e92c5fb7b05d6ae9291
Closes-Bug: #1839384
"}, {'created': '2020-03-20 21:17:57.000000000', 'message': "NetApp ONTAP: Fix iSCSI multiattach volume terminates connection

When detaching a volume from an instance, NetApp ONTAP driver terminates
the iSCSI connection, even if there're other connections to the LUN from
the same initiator. This terminates connections to the LUN from other
instances running on the same host.

This patch fixes this bug by leaving the connection untouched if there
are other connections from the same initiator. Now the connection is
terminated only if it's the last one from the same initiator.

Change-Id: I0b8b5930c9e8f3c049b82e92c5fb7b05d6ae9291
Closes-Bug: #1839384
"}, {'created': '2020-03-23 22:17:23.000000000', 'message': "NetApp ONTAP: Fix iSCSI multiattach volume terminates connection

When detaching a volume from an instance, NetApp ONTAP driver terminates
the iSCSI connection, even if there're other connections to the LUN from
the same initiator. This terminates connections to the LUN from other
instances running on the same host.

This patch fixes this bug by leaving the connection untouched if there

commit_message:
NetApp ONTAP: Fix iSCSI multiattach volume terminates connection

When detaching a volume from an instance, NetApp ONTAP driver terminates
the iSCSI connection, even if there're other connections to the LUN from
the same initiator. This terminates connections to the LUN from other
instances running on the same host.

This patch fixes this bug by leaving the connection untouched if there
are other connections from the same initiator. Now the connection is
terminated only if it's the last one from the same initiator.

Change-Id: I0b8b5930c9e8f3c049b82e92c5fb7b05d6ae9291
Closes-Bug: #1839384

(cherry picked from commit 52af9fcc11bee72135ffefcc982db8055556f516)
'}, {'created': '2020-05-06 23:16:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix designate-sink shutdown issue

If no notification handler is configured the
designate-sink may not shutdown properly.
This is because the listener was created but never

commit_message:
Fix designate-sink shutdown issue

If no notification handler is configured the
designate-sink may not shutdown properly.
This is because the listener was created but never
started. This caused oslo.messaging to hang on
waiting for a successful start before stopping.

Closes-Bug: #1877201
Change-Id: Ie51f7c3d64cbb48ae359256b6fa5a0196fb3f248
(cherry picked from commit 40cbc9bd43d3b43d6cdc4daeb5a089df96603ed7)

commit_message:
Fix designate-sink shutdown issue

If no notification handler is configured the
designate-sink may not shutdown properly.
This is because the listener was created but never
started. This caused oslo.messaging to hang on
waiting for a successful start before stopping.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/725977
Closes-Bug: #1877201
Change-Id: Ie51f7c3d64cbb48ae359256b6fa5a0196fb3f248

commit_message:
Spliting tempest validate and install role

Splitting the validate-yaml in two: install_skiplist and
validate_yaml. Also renaming the role to use underscore '_'
instead of dash '-' becase it will be required in future
ansible version.

The reason to this split is to reuse these roles when start
to use it in other installers, instead of reinvent the
wheel.

Change-Id: I2a736723087016db3eebf20cea48fadb658ba436

commit_message:
Do not try to connect to mons when everything is provided

We shouldn't try to access monitors in case deployer has provided both
ceph config and ceph auth.
So that deployers wouldn't have to provide access to their ceph clusters
to the deploy host.

Change-Id: If0b4319826abd8991a81d39ca049e8063a667685
(cherry picked from commit d572e873df8928600fd9a86f94b69b76969c0cf1)

commit_message:
Upgrade centos in dockerfiles and fix OVN gate

Somehow an update to centos repos and the fact that docker.io centos
containers weren't updated for a while broke us. To fix this we need to
make sure RPMs in the container are upgraded, otherwise `yum history
undo last` fails miserably with missing packages errors.

Also this commit makes sure installation dies when we're unable to build
containers.

(cherry picked from commit 139b912365a465a387e2921f0c70683fb942f539)

Fix ovn gate

The repo networking-ovn moved to ovn-octavia-provider. We should
move the CI to install OVN from the Neutron repo.

(cherry picked from commit c77a38f8a11046c9cff2c4d395610fad264d2e0f)

Change-Id: I29e19e13aa22047bfa07817a7794fc18612bbc32

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2020-05-06 17:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2020-05-06 17:45:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Ghanshyam, 

I'm restructuring the old legacy "LVM job" in manila to be a zuulv3 native style job. I'm making this new job derive from devstack-tempest-ipv6 because I'd like to keep coverage to the test you added in the Train cycle to ensure we're deploying an IPv6 service/control plane. I'm however, dropping the "ipv6-only" naming from the job. What are your views on that? In manila, we care that this job does data path testing with IPv4 and IPv6; so calling it "ipv6-only" is a bit confusing. What's the reasoning behind this naming? Wonder if we can just drop it and still be okay. 

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-05-06 17:59:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Hi Ghanshyam,
 > 
 > I'm restructuring the old legacy "LVM job" in manila to be a zuulv3
 > native style job. I'm making this new job derive from
 > devstack-tempest-ipv6 because I'd like to keep coverage to the test
 > you added in the Train cycle to ensure we're deploying an IPv6
 > service/control plane. I'm however, dropping the "ipv6-only" naming
 > from the job. What are your views on that? In manila, we care that
 > this job does data path testing with IPv4 and IPv6; so calling it
 > "ipv6-only" is a bit confusing. What's the reasoning behind this
 > naming? Wonder if we can just drop it and still be okay.
 > 
 > Thanks!

devstack-tempest-ipv6 base job set SERVICE_IP_VERSION=6 so that every openstack service and DB etc listen on ipv6 address not on ipv4. If you see on the log, you will be able to see manila also communicate on ipv6. I have not checked the tests testing the IPV4 data path but if that is there then we can verify it.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2020-05-06 18:01:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

just a small issue (if I read it correctly):'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-05-06 18:02:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> > Hi Ghanshyam,
 > >
 > > I'm restructuring the old legacy "LVM job" in manila to be a
 > zuulv3
 > > native style job. I'm making this new job derive from
 > > devstack-tempest-ipv6 because I'd like to keep coverage to the
 > test
 > > you added in the Train cycle to ensure we're deploying an IPv6
 > > service/control plane. I'm however, dropping the "ipv6-only"
 > naming
 > > from the job. What are your views on that? In manila, we care
 > that
 > > this job does data path testing with IPv4 and IPv6; so calling it
 > > "ipv6-only" is a bit confusing. What's the reasoning behind this
 > > naming? Wonder if we can just drop it and still be okay.
 > >
 > > Thanks!
 > 
 > devstack-tempest-ipv6 base job set SERVICE_IP_VERSION=6 so that
 > every openstack service and DB etc listen on ipv6 address not on
 > ipv4. If you see on the log, you will be able to see manila also
 > communicate on ipv6. I have not checked the tests testing the IPV4
 > data path but if that is there then we can verify it.

to configure the dual stack for neutron, you need to set the IP_VERSION=4+6 in devstack job. so either you set control plan listing on ipv4(devstack-tempest) or ipv6(devstack-tempest-ipv6) and set IP_VERSION=4+6 for dual stack configuration.'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2020-05-06 18:06:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> devstack-tempest-ipv6 base job set SERVICE_IP_VERSION=6 so that every openstack service and DB etc listen on ipv6 address not on ipv4. If you see on the log, you will be able to see manila also communicate on ipv6. I have not checked the tests testing the IPV4 data path but if that is there then we can verify it.

Yes - You can see this in the last run; and I'd like to preserve this behavior. However, we'll drop the suffix in the job name: "ipv6-only".

 -  the environment supports both IPv4 and IPv6 (IP_VERSION=4+6)
 - The control plane is on IPv6 (SERVICE_IP_VERSION=6)

So, in this environment, Nova VMs can still be provisioned on IPv4 only private project networks, and be connected via Floating IPs. This is what matters to manila, since we perform access control via client IP addresses, and test the data path by mounting shares and writing data. For this, we don't care if the service/control plane is on IPv6.'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2020-05-06 18:29:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2020-05-06 19:47:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2020-05-06 19:53:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2020-05-06 22:01:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

Will refresh this change after https://review.opendev.org/#/c/725461/ merges - can't have a dependency on manila while I have backports pending in manila.."}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2020-05-07 03:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2020-05-07 11:01:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2020-05-07 11:43:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2020-05-07 12:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add stable/ussuri job on master gate

Now we have stable/ussuri branch ready for devstack
and so does for all service projects.

This commit adds the stable/ussuri job on tempest plugin
master gate.

commit_message:
Add a helpful error message to openstack_upgrade_availble()

After spending time debugging a missing package codename, I felt it
would be useful to add an error message as to why it might be
happening.  Hopefully useful in the next round of upgrades.

Change-Id: Ie994f49847b50c1b10e4b76845099cdd09441ecd

subject: Use floating ip for interface ip if it exists
messages: [{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-05-07 13:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-05-07 13:11:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-05-07 13:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nnevermind'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-07 13:10:57.000000000', 'message': "Use floating ip for interface ip if it exists

While floating ips are an abomination and should be scourged from
the earth, nonetheless they are sadly a common case for many people.
For the poor souls who are forced to reside in a networking model
that's inferior to my home internet connection, we can still infer
that if there is a floating ip, it is the address intended to be
used for external communication.

Also, while we're in there - don't trust accessIPv4 - it has no
idea what it's talking about.

Change-Id: Ifb890f1bb462bd41c1e38949bdaaa8ca1ce7c93b
"}, {'created': '2020-05-07 13:11:29.000000000', 'message': "Use floating ip for interface ip if it exists

In clouds with floating ips, we can safely infer
that if there is a floating ip, it is the address intended to be
used for external communication.

Also, while we're in there - don't trust accessIPv4 - it has no
idea what it's talking about.

Change-Id: Ifb890f1bb462bd41c1e38949bdaaa8ca1ce7c93b
"}]
commit_message:
Use floating ip for interface ip if it exists

In clouds with floating ips, we can safely infer
that if there is a floating ip, it is the address intended to be
used for external communication.

Also, while we're in there - don't trust accessIPv4 - it has no
idea what it's talking about.

Change-Id: Ifb890f1bb462bd41c1e38949bdaaa8ca1ce7c93b

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-06 15:49:13.000000000', 'message': "[OVN] Bump up transaction timeout for functional tests

We still can see occasional failures because of timeouts
in the test_ovn_db_sync tests, like 1 failure per week.

As per agreement during last IRC meeting we decided to
bump up the functional tests timout from 15 seconds to 30 seconds,
because we're still pretty behind the default value of 180 seconds.

Change-Id: Ib20cdd0bb7d24795c8bd5c84c6143000b9922b4d
Related-Bug: 1868110
"}]
commit_message:
[OVN] Bump up transaction timeout for functional tests

We still can see occasional failures because of timeouts
in the test_ovn_db_sync tests, like 1 failure per week.

As per agreement during last IRC meeting we decided to
bump up the functional tests timout from 15 seconds to 30 seconds,
because we're still pretty behind the default value of 180 seconds.

Change-Id: Ib20cdd0bb7d24795c8bd5c84c6143000b9922b4d
Related-Bug: 1868110

commit_message:
BUILD_TIMEOUT is not needed

The option BUILD_TIMEOUT has been deprecated in Pike and renamed to
IRONIC_TEMPEST_BUILD_TIMEOUT, only not ironic services use it, so
it can be removed in this case.

Change-Id: I7caf35f67fe5c93b0d35bd227a418cfadd0f3f20

subject: Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-11 18:49:36.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I0b60250038ae2e8eb9dc12f1c4f2f23e64309690
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I0b60250038ae2e8eb9dc12f1c4f2f23e64309690

commit_message:

stable/ussuri.

subject: Remove monotonic usage
messages: [{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-05-04 22:16:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2020-05-07 12:06:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-04 22:16:46.000000000', 'message': 'Remove monotonic usage

The monotonic package was needed for monotonic time operations when
running under Python runtimes older than 3.3. Since we now only support
versions higher than this, this third party package requirement can now
be removed.

Change-Id: I0cb0339c5e681b63783828cfde9921dfd6727f50
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Remove monotonic usage

The monotonic package was needed for monotonic time operations when
running under Python runtimes older than 3.3. Since we now only support
versions higher than this, this third party package requirement can now
be removed.

Change-Id: I0cb0339c5e681b63783828cfde9921dfd6727f50
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

Remove monotonic usage

The monotonic package was needed for monotonic time operations when
running under Python runtimes older than 3.3. Since we now only support
versions higher than this, this third party package requirement can now
be removed.

Change-Id: I809de2f6fe257c80de7c81f9e08499a919f52ff8
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Conditionally restore default route in setup_ipv6

Restoring the default IPv6 route is not needed in CI and
fails when there are multiple defaults, but it is useful
in local devstacks where multiple default routes are not
typical.

Add a variable in settings and use it to make this behavior
conditional and set it to False for the lvm job.

Closes-bug: #1836788
Change-Id: Id73de8100509ec5935641f5f35f93f482d108bcd
(cherry picked from commit 70e908344dd4db81652264a2de2c04ce9666bb46)
(cherry picked from commit 99c0a110920910bfd379d544e7085daca90b1132)
(cherry picked from commit 682d6b6ee17e8abb4038ca304bee839463424838)

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6681, 'name': 'Brent Eagles', 'email': 'beagles@redhat.com', 'username': 'beagles'}, {'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 11975, 'name': 'Slawek Kaplonski', 'email': 'skaplons@redhat.com', 'username': 'slaweq'}, {'_account_id': 12398, 'name': 'Dan Sneddon', 'email': 'dsneddon@redhat.com', 'username': 'dsneddon'}, {'_account_id': 13995, 'name': 'Nate Johnston', 'email': 'nate.johnston@redhat.com', 'username': 'natejohnston'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 17823, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@redhat.com', 'username': 'mbaldessari'}, {'_account_id': 21798, 'name': 'Bernard Cafarelli', 'email': 'bcafarel@redhat.com', 'username': 'bcafarel'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24245, 'name': 'Harald JensÃ¥s', 'email': 'hjensas@redhat.com', 'username': 'harald.jensas'}, {'_account_id': 28223, 'name': 'Cedric Jeanneret', 'display_name': 'cjeanner (Tengu)', 'email': 'cjeanner@redhat.com', 'username': 'cjeanner'}]

[{'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-27 10:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-27 10:14:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-27 10:19:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-27 12:19:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-27 13:14:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2020-04-27 23:14:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

This is pretty cool, but I think there might be some performance issues. What do you think about using your non-blocking write to the pipe in the wrapper but make the sync service a simple (non-oneshot) service running a loop with blocking reads? This would allow the agent to fire in startup requests without blocking and the sync service would fire up sidecars as quickly as it can. Would this remove the need for locks and systemd.path nofications?'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-28 07:04:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> This would allow the agent to fire in startup requests without blocking and the sync service would fire up sidecars as quickly as it can.

If neutron commands to start processes w/o waiting for completion, but instead only waiting for pidfiles created - that would still keep this solution firing up containers as fast as possible, e.g.:

Neutron agent calls for a command and enters the wrapper (shall not wait for the command to exit!) -> wrapper adds a job into pipe, non-blocking, pokes the date -> path unit triggers sync (still ~0 delay here up to that moment) -> sync does blocking read from pipe and instantly gets a result -> starts container, pidfile created -> neutron catches up this event to mark the original command DONE.

So that depends on how exactly neutron processes its commands loop.

> Would this remove the need for locks and systemd.path nofications?

I think that would be a too much disruptive design change.
And a shared pipe, at least for writing jobs in, would anyway require locks for safe processing on the wrappers' side. I've read [0] about the safety guarantees for concurrent access to FIFO pipes and that PIPE_BUF thingy and my takeaway was ...use locks :)

[0] https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/write.html#tag_16_685"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-28 07:13:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-28 07:19:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-28 07:22:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-28 07:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-28 07:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

on my system, the cap for individual pipes is 1M:

cat /proc/sys/fs/pipe-max-size
1048576'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-28 07:53:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Brent, here is the snippet showing timestamps of haproxy wrappers called from OVB's compute-0 node https://pastebin.com/NXk183W1

https://logserver.rdoproject.org/73/723373/5/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/9294013/logs/overcloud-novacompute-0/var/log/containers/neutron/ovn-metadata-agent.log.txt.gz"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-29 08:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

hi, could you folks please answer my comments? thanks!
Please also try testing this patch for your best matching networking CI cases.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-29 09:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-29 13:48:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2020-04-29 13:49:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> > This would allow the agent to fire in startup requests without
 > blocking and the sync service would fire up sidecars as quickly as
 > it can.
 > 
 > If neutron commands to start processes w/o waiting for completion,
 > but instead only waiting for pidfiles created - that would still
 > keep this solution firing up containers as fast as possible, e.g.:
 > 
 > Neutron agent calls for a command and enters the wrapper (shall not
 > wait for the command to exit!) -> wrapper adds a job into pipe,
 > non-blocking, pokes the date -> path unit triggers sync (still ~0
 > delay here up to that moment) -> sync does blocking read from pipe
 > and instantly gets a result -> starts container, pidfile created ->
 > neutron catches up this event to mark the original command DONE.
 
IIUC this means that the wrapper effectively blocks until the sync reads from the pipe?
 
 > So that depends on how exactly neutron processes its commands loop.

Right. How neutron processes syncs and subprocess launches makes this a little more interesting. If it allows multiple concurrent launches somehow, the resultant ordering might get interesting... not broken, just interesting. You've handled this case by probing the pipe and just refeeding the result back in.

 > > Would this remove the need for locks and systemd.path
 > nofications?
 > 
 > I think that would be a too much disruptive design change.
 > And a shared pipe, at least for writing jobs in, would anyway
 > require locks for safe processing on the wrappers' side. I've read
 > [0] about the safety guarantees for concurrent access to FIFO pipes
 > and that PIPE_BUF thingy and my takeaway was ...use locks :)
 > 
 > [0] https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/write.html#tag_16_685

I think writes are meant to be atomic up to a certain size, but the dd thing might break that. Better safe than sorry in any case."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-29 13:51:51.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to side-cars-1874470'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2020-04-29 13:57:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-29 14:39:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> IIUC this means that the wrapper effectively blocks until the sync reads from the pipe?

right, but the trigger events immediately follow submission of jobs into the pipe. Having those tightly coupled makes the waiting time in blocking state as short as possible. In fact, the sync script acts like a simple oneshot daemon :D'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-29 14:42:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> the resultant ordering might get interesting... not broken, just interesting

indeed, reordering commands may bring unexpected results, if reordered kill and start commands :) And resubmitting jobs into queue can change the order of jobs for sure!'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2020-04-29 16:34:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

Let me make sure I understand the logical flow here.  I am not addressing the locking in the sync script as that is a separate issue and IMHO unnecessary.

At system startup, systemd starts the sync script.  The sync script blocks on reading from the FIFO.  This happens while systemd starts neutron l3 container.  Then, an L3 failover event occurs.  The neutron l3 agent now needs to spin up a hundred haproxy processes.  The process that happens is:

1. neutron l3 container thread starts wrapper script.  The agent can spawn multiple threads so this can happen concurrently.

2. Each wrapper script writes to the FIFO, using locking so they do not overwrite each other.

3. The sync script is waiting to read from the pipe.  Once a newline is sent the read completes and the sync script runs systemd start to start a new sidecar.

4. The sync script exits and systemd starts a new one.

Steps 1 and 2 will loop within the neutron l3 container; steps 3 and 4 loop on the hypervisor.

Here are my concerns:

A.) We are going from a state where multiple containers could be started simultaneously by the many neutron l3 agent threads, to one where only one container can be started at a time, bottlenecked by the sync script.

B.) I worry that a systemd unit spinning very very quickly as the sync script keeps getting respawned will have a negative impact on systemd and/or some other component that is depending on it.

Please let me know if I have misunderstood the way this is supposed to flow.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2020-04-29 16:35:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Giving this a -1 because the locking in the sync script is highly problematic.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 07:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 07:28:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

> At system startup, systemd starts the sync script.  The sync script blocks on reading from the FIFO.  This happens while systemd starts 

The path unit gets started. It notifies the oneshot sync service as new jobs arrive into the wrappers in containers.

> neutron l3 container.  Then, an L3 failover event occurs.  The neutron l3 agent now needs to spin up a hundred haproxy processes.  The process that happens is:
>
> 1. neutron l3 container thread starts wrapper script.  The agent can spawn multiple threads so this can happen concurrently.
>
> 2. Each wrapper script writes to the FIFO, using locking so they do not overwrite each other.
>
> 3. The sync script is waiting to read from the pipe.  Once a newline is sent the read completes and the sync script runs systemd start to start a new sidecar.

It does not much waiting because of updating the fifo and sending a trigger to the path unit are tightly coupled events. Blocking only synchronizes sync with the job(s) posted into fifo by wrappers.

> 4. The sync script exits and systemd starts a new one.

Not exactly. Sync only "wakes up" upon new updates from the path unit.

> Steps 1 and 2 will loop within the neutron l3 container; steps 3 and 4 loop on the hypervisor.

There *used to* be a loop in the sync originally. But as the path unit merges events and misses notifies while the sync running, that proved to be wrong approach. This rework proposes no loops on the host. Events based notifications trigger the sync. That's not exactly a loop in its classical meaning. While the read&resubmit loop indeed happens, but in an arbitrary wrapper. It is rather "capture the flag" contest. Locking ensures the "write jobs into fifo" flag is only held by at most one instance of the wrapper at any time. This loop is made to never miss notifications from the path unit. If that happened that a job was left behind in the pipe, the wrapper that "captured the flag" picks it up, resubmits and notifies the sync again.

> Here are my concerns:
>
> A.) We are going from a state where multiple containers could be started simultaneously by the many neutron l3 agent threads, to one where only one container can be started at a time, bottlenecked by the sync script.

The sync script since its beginning was serial and starting containers only one by one. Multiple wrappers was writing into the jobs file instead a pipe. And merged update events resulted in truncated jobs file and lost jobs.

> B.) I worry that a systemd unit spinning very very quickly as the sync script keeps getting respawned will have a negative impact on systemd and/or some other component that is depending on it.

I hope that the systemd path unit feature was designed bearing in mind 
a possibility of quick inotify events generated for the watched path :)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 07:43:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 09:07:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 09:10:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

note, read locks are still needed for wrappers and sync service.
That guarantees no reading from fifo while being posted a job by a wrapper.

Also, shortened the minimum wrapper exec time to ~0.3s. Prioritized the  wrapped command to come first into fifo. For a corner case when a job was read in busy loop but failed getting a lock for writing it back: added processing the file containing abandoned jobs.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 09:14:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 09:18:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 09:19:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

I think this is a final version. Can't think of improving this more."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-04-30 09:24:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2020-04-30 18:29:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

recheck maybe a pypi error'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-04-30 18:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-04 07:00:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-04 07:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-05-07 12:09:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-27 10:09:56.000000000', 'message': "Ensure side-car wrappers never miss sync events

Systemd path units merge consequent notifications for update events sent
to the watched object, if the target (sync service) has yet completed
its jobs.

In order to never miss updates for side-car container wrappers, make
sure there is no loops executed in the sync service script. Instead, use
a FIFO pipe as a source of jobs for the sync script. Keep it oneshot,
but make it self blocking, when it's waiting for a job.

Move the looping logic for all jobs pending for sync to the commands
wrapper. Use file locks to exclusively access the shared pipe and post
there jobs for the sync service. The jobs are posted in async and
non-blocking fashion. The only exit criterion for all running wrapper
instances is an empty state if the shared pipe.

Closes-bug: #1874470

Change-Id: Idbaa284c7337fa472a1cc16a3543bd9e6c995044
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-04-27 10:14:41.000000000', 'message': "Ensure side-car wrappers never miss sync events

Change-Id: Idbaa284c7337fa472a1cc16a3543bd9e6c995044
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-04-30 07:02:34.000000000', 'message': "Ensure side-car wrappers never miss sync events

Systemd path units merge consequent notifications for update events sent
to the watched object, if the target (sync service) has yet completed
its jobs.

In order to never miss updates for side-car container wrappers, make
sure there is no loops executed in the sync service script. Instead, use
a FIFO pipe as a source of jobs for the sync script. Keep it oneshot,
but make it self blocking, when it's waiting for a job.

Move the looping logic for all jobs pending for sync to the commands
wrapper. Use file locks to exclusively access the shared pipe and post
there jobs for the sync service. The jobs are posted in async and
non-blocking fashion. The only exit criterion for all running wrapper
instances is an empty state of the shared pipe.

This also frees the sync script off using any locks. Having a lock on
the service_wrapper side makes sense to ensure there is not write
contention. But since the sync script is a singleton it's fine for the
it to just read from the fifo pipe. The 'read' will wait for an end
of line before proceeding. If we have a hundred haproxy sidecars that
need to start then blocking on the lock will really exacerbate things
otherwise.

Closes-bug: #1874470
Change-Id: Idbaa284c7337fa472a1cc16a3543bd9e6c995044

"}, {'created': '2020-04-30 09:07:23.000000000', 'message': "Ensure side-car wrappers never miss sync events

Systemd path units merge consequent notifications for update events sent
to the watched object, if the target (sync service) has yet completed
its jobs.

In order to never miss updates for side-car container wrappers, make
sure there is no loops executed in the sync service script. Instead, use

but make it self blocking, when it's waiting for a job.

wrapper. Use file locks to access the shared pipe and post
there jobs for the sync service. The jobs are posted in async and
non-blocking fashion. The only exit criterion for all running wrapper
instances is an empty state of the shared pipe. The price to pay for
this is the minimal execution time of a wrapper is extended by a ~0.3s.

This also frees the sync script off using any locks. Having a lock on
the service_wrapper side makes sense to ensure there is not write
contention. But since the sync script is a singleton it's fine for the
it to just read from the fifo pipe. The 'read' will wait for an end
of line before proceeding. If we have a hundred haproxy sidecars that
need to start then blocking on the lock will really exacerbate things
otherwise.

commit_message:
Ensure side-car wrappers never miss sync events

Systemd path units merge consequent notifications for update events sent
to the watched object, if the target (sync service) has yet completed
its jobs.

In order to never miss updates for side-car container wrappers, make
sure there is no loops executed in the sync service script. Instead, use
a FIFO pipe as a source of jobs for the sync script. Keep it oneshot,
but make it self blocking, when it's waiting for a job.

Move the looping logic for all jobs pending for sync to the commands
wrapper. Use file locks to access the shared pipe and post
there jobs for the sync service. The jobs are posted in async and
non-blocking fashion. The only exit criterion for all running wrapper
instances is an empty state of the shared pipe. The price to pay for
this is the minimal execution time of a wrapper is extended by a ~0.3s.

This also frees the sync script off using any locks. Having a lock on
the service_wrapper side makes sense to ensure there is not write
contention. But since the sync script is a singleton it's fine for the
it to just read from the fifo pipe. The 'read' will wait for an end
of line before proceeding. If we have a hundred haproxy sidecars that
need to start then blocking on the lock will really exacerbate things
otherwise.

Closes-bug: #1874470
Change-Id: Idbaa284c7337fa472a1cc16a3543bd9e6c995044
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-07 10:04:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add opinionated password_hash_algorithm

The default password hash algorithm bcrypt, since pike, has drastic
degradation impacts on the overall scalability.

Add KeystonePasswordHashAlgorithm, which sets password_hash_algorithm
in hiera to pbkdf2_sha512. The user passwords need to be reset to take
full effect.

Change-Id: I8e16d79385844893fcfe1583359ae553e45a2e12
Closes-Bug: #1871347
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add opinionated password_hash_algorithm

The default password hash algorithm bcrypt, since pike, has drastic
degradation impacts on the overall scalability.

Add KeystonePasswordHashAlgorithm, which sets password_hash_algorithm
in hiera to pbkdf2_sha512. The user passwords need to be reset to take
full effect.

Change-Id: I8e16d79385844893fcfe1583359ae553e45a2e12
Closes-Bug: #1871347
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
